data.title: Harvey william cushing

data.text:
1. Dr.R.Durai Arasan M.D., Department of Physiology, Coimbatore medical college.

2. Synopsis  Early life and childhood  Education  Personal life  Early career  Experimental studies  Discoveries  World war 1  Contributions  Journal publications  Late career and death  Awards and honors  Posthumous  Summary

3. Early life and childhood  Birth – April 8, 1869  Place – Cleveland, Ohio, USA  Father – Henry William Cushing (physician)  Mother – Betsey Williams  Family of 10 children

4. Education  Schooling – Cleveland Manual Training School  Graduation – A.B degree (Bachelor of Arts) from Yale university in 1891  Medical degree – Harvard Medical School (1895)  Internship – Massachusetts General Hospital

5. Personal life  Married to – Katharine Stone Crowell (1902)  5 children William Harvey Cushing Mary Benedict Cushing Betsey Cushing – James Roosevelt Henry Kirke Cushing Barbara Cushing

6. Early career  Residency in surgery – Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore under the surveillance of William Stewart Halsted(surgeon)  Favorite student of Sir William Osler (Canadian physician)  Went abroad to Europe and studied cerebral surgery along with Theodor Kocher at Bern, Switzerland (surgeon- Nobel prize 1909) Charles Sherrington at Liverpool, UK (neurophysiologist – Nobel prize 1932)

7. Experimental Studies  With Kocher - intracranial pressure  With Sherrington - localisation of cerebral centers  With William Halsted - local anaesthesia  With William T. Bovie - electrocautery Kocher Sherrington Halsted Bovie

8. Discoveries  Cushing reflex - relation between blood pressure and intracranial pressure (1901)  Due to increased intracranial pressure - results in increased systolic pressure, bradycardia, irregular respiration – Cushing triad  Experimented in dogs, monitored the caliber and color of cortical vessels by fitting a glass window into the skull of the dog

9. Discoveries  Cushing disease – 1912  Described as Polyglandular syndrome  Published – 1932 The Basophil Adenomas of the Pituitary Body and Their Clinical Manifestations: pituitary Basophilism  Condition where pituitary secretes excess ACTH

10. Discoveries  Cushing forceps  Discovered the use of mercury manometer along with Scipione Riva Rocci (Italian physician) in 1896  Most widely used untill Nikoloi Korotkov discovered Korotkoff sounds in 1905

11. World war 1  Joined US Army Medical Corps in 1917  British Expeditionary forces in France – experimented with electromagnets to remove shrapnels  Promoted to Lieutenant Colonel and then to Colonel in 1918 where he worked with Lieutenant Edward Osler  Discharged 1919

12. Contributions  Numerous monographs on cerebral surgery and spinal column surgery  Papers on bacteriology  Developed the method of operating with local anaesthesia, and his paper on its use in hernia gave him a European reputation  Used x-rays to diagnose brain tumors

13. Contributions  Improved considerably the survival of patients after difficult brain operations for intracranial tumors  Used electrical stimuli for study of the human sensory cortex  Was the world's leading teacher of neurosurgeons in the first decades of 20th century  Cushing ulcer – head injury (raised intracranial pressure)

14. Journal Publications  The Pituitary Body and its Disorders (1912)  Tumours of the Nervus Acousticus (1917)  Blood Vessel Tumours of the Brain (1928)  Consecratio Medici and other papers (1928)  The Medical Career (1940)

15. Late career and death  Retired to Yale school of medicine (1933-37)  Passed away on 7 october 1939 at New Haven, Connecticut  cause of death - myocardial infarction. (cyst in 3rd ventricle?)  Interred at Lake view cemetary, Cleveland.

16. Awards and honors  Father of neurosurgery (Ernest Sachs)  Companion of Bath by British government (1919)  Distinguished service medal by US government (1919)  Pulitzer prize for biography on Sir William Osler (1926)  Lister medal for surgery (1930)  Nobel prize - 38 nominations

17. Posthumous  US postal stamp – 1988  Yale university named library after him  Opened a museum of his brain specimens
